bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Guiellermo Lage, November 27, 1941

div1.p: Hench sends Lage a reprint of his yellow fever article, and hopes that he will see it as the beginning of efforts to publicize the work of Finlay among Americans. He hopes the Cubans will learn more about Reed and his colleagues, as well.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Guiellermo Lage, November 27, 1941
div1.opener:
November 27, 1941
Dr. Guierllermo Lage
Assistant Director
Finlay Institute
Havana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Lage:
div1.p:
I am sending to you with my best wishes a reprint of an
address I gave last June when Walter Reed's daughter unveiled in
Cleveland a painting dedicated to The Conquerors of Yellow Fever.
In this painting Dr. Carlos Finlay, your great compatriot, holds a
high and honored place. In my address I tried to cover consider-
able ground in a short space and could give all too brief mention
of the great work of Dr. Finlay, but I plan to continue my investi-
gations on the history of the conquest of yellow fever and hope to
publish in the future a detailed account.

I hope you and your colleagues will see in this painting
and in this address at least a beginning--a step in the direction
of giving due honor to Dr. Finlay. We in America need to know more
about him and in turn we want our Cuban friends to know more of
Reed and his colleagues. Together they splendidly served humanity.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
